content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun and simple

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting for a clash.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle tests the thinking capability and logical side of programmer to code it in the right way. It is simple as well as challenging in just the right proportion.
This is quite an interesting puzzle. I would have loved to solve it. :))
Thats useful :)
Good puzzle

The first line of the input does help slightly with coding time.  It would be preferential to have it built into the starting boilerplate rather than being input each time, given its constant nature.

Otherwise it feels about the right level of hardness and should be accomplishable in 15 minutes for most devs.
This might be a matter of taste, but I wouldn't include Line 1 as input. Instead, I would just place it in the description of the problem as this information doesn't change.

Good puzzle!

In the description:
- If Y counts as a vowel, it shouldn't be in the consonants map.
- the consonants map doesn't line up; please remove the leading spaces.

If the vowels list and the consonants list are the same in every test, they don't need to be per-test inputs - they'd be better off just provided in the Statement.

Please state that case is preserved for each letter (uppercase letters stay uppercase, lowercase letters stay lowercase).

You can disappoint your primary school teacher ))
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E4cvSsW3Lyk

Goal section
* You may use the `monospace` syntax to format the conversion tables. And you may also remove all the quotation marks that way.

* Please use a full stop at the end of every sentence.

Input section
* Line 2: Please change "word" to "message", as the message can contain more than one word.

Output section
* Please change "word" to "message".

* Not sure if "translation" is the right word to use here. I would write "the decoded message" instead.

Thanks.

" the first vowel is replaced by the last, the second by the second last and so on:
("a", "e", "i", "o", "u", "y") have been replaced by the opposite vowel:
↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓
("y", "e", "i", "o", "u", "y") "

The conversion table is not good ! It should be : 

("a", "e", "i", "o", "u", "y") 
↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓
("y", "u", "o", "i", "e", "a") 

Otherwise, what does this sentence mean ? "If the letter of the coded message is a consonant then it remains a consonant" 
If the character in the coded message is a consonant, do we have to convert it or no ? If yes, why should we have to convert it to a vowel... 
This sentence is not clear, you should remove it because it does not make sense after reading the table conversion for consonants
Sorry for this error on my part
it's normally good now

Wikipedia ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vowel ) entry says:

In English, the word vowel is commonly used to refer both to vowel sounds and to the written symbols that represent them (a, e, i, o, u, and sometimes y).
Having the lists in the inputs does help to save some time needed for copying and pasting though :D

I guess, part in brackets applies to vowel SOUNDS. And since message consists of letters, not sounds, you can see, for example, definition in Oxford Dictionary (part 2):
https://www.oxfordlearnersdictionaries.com/definition/english/vowel

Interesting. Wikipedia's description of "symbols that represent them [the sounds]" are in the form of "letters" too, right?

The puzzle is at least based on a loose definition of vowel, and not on fake ideas. Otherwise that'll be a serious issue.
Erm... I can't see any changes in Goal section?

Try this:
```a e i o u y
↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓
y u o i e a```

The other letters can be formatted similarly.
Could you please finish formatting the other conversion table? Thanks.
